review_title: Nice environment, great students, offset by very low pay when compared to other institutions.
pros: Love the campus environment and architecture. Positive student involvement. Relatively close to me in commuting.
cons: The pay is almost 1/2 of what I was receiving for equivalent classes taught at another Christian university. My pay is comparable to what I made about 9 or 10 years ago. I am not sure how they can keep faculty around at that low of a rate. These days, the cost of commuting is causing me to re-think the idea to continue working here. I essentially made this same money tutoring.

review_title: Fantastic Position but dont get too attached

Great Supervisors
Decent Hours
Good Working Environment (most of the time)
Great Variety of positions to work in

There were a few people there who were constantly rude to me and did everything they could to hinder my progress getting to where I wanted to go, which was incredibly annoying, because they could whisper slanders in my sups ears and make sure that I don't end up doing what I love.

Workplace Politics are a serious game at this event center, watch out.

The employment also ends in one semester spurts, so if you're not on the dollar, you might never end up getting another semester.

job_title: International Admissions Student Worker in Copenhagen, Capital Region
pros:
If you are a student, it is very convenient
I learned a lot of office skills like how to be a receptionist, process documents, and write professionally
Great way to establish friendships and community with people you normally may not have had the chance to meet
Flexible hours that accommodated my school schedule, supervisor was really understanding
This office really cares about students and puts in extra effort, time, and energy for their international students
cons:
Minimum wage is all you are going to be able to get
Our student worker team put in at least twice as much effort and work than any other student worker job on campus but didn't have any opportunities to advance or get more benefits for it
Felt out of the loop of new information and would only hear second hand like the introduction of new majors or when we were scheduled to give tours

job_title: Front Desk Receptionist in Riverside, CA
pros: I work as the receptionist in an office, I am also a graduate student here. So being able to have a part-time job where I still have time to focus on my school is great! My also has a lot of graduate assistants who still have time for their studies. I work closely with the upper management and can appreciate the group of positive and supportive people who lead this office.
cons: I guess I would say it is very easy to get stuck in the CBU Christian bubble. Since a majority of the offices are built on being Christ like and being authentically good to each other, you can forget there is a different environment out there.

pros: Pros are the generally Christian, welcoming attitude of fellow staff members and on-campus food selection is decent.
cons: A lot of the staff are very clique-y, almost reminiscent of high school. Some people have worked there their entire working career and can get away with anything. Every office has its own culture, but as a general rule, expect leadership to be lazy. Parking.

pros: Christian work environment with a great reputation in the community. Great benefits and 403B match.
cons: Seems most people are hired because they know someone, so it can be difficult for an outsider to gain respect and trust. Lots of  clicks who stick together and close others out. People talk too much; there are no secrets and what you think is said in private will most likely be shared with someone who tells someone else.

review_title: fair and honest work environment, should not pay all student workers minimum wage
pros: Straight forward, not too much politics involved for this kind of institution. The location is nice and the benefits come right away with first day of work.
cons: Advancement is hard to obtain, the work load can be really versatile compared to the season, there is always something going on which makes the employees life sometimes difficult.

pros: Work with college schedule and sometimes flexible.
cons: Can only work part-time because CBU doesnt want to give student workers or other staff any benefits. They are very strict, and cap the maximum of 28 hours a week. Some managers can be unreasonable, some are pleasant and truly represent their Chrisitan values they claim to have. No pay raises either....

pros: I loved the work, and since it was on campus, it was easy for me to tailor my work schedule to work with my class schedule, and I could walk to work because I was living on campus.
cons: My coworkers made the job less pleasant, and the pay was less than minimum wage because California Baptist University is a private university.

review_title: Six years employed at California Baptist University
